results.notes: Thought to share this find in here aswell. These tiny and fragile Pholiotina species fruited on my yard about two weeks ago and since then I’ve observed them on the side of the road within 500m from my house. I’ve been finding them in small numbers since 2014 and this year in great numbers. I think they’re likely either Pholiotina cyanopus or Pholiotina smithii, but I don’t have access to microscope so this is as far as I can get with the identification. The described habitats of Pholiotina smithii seems to fit better and since they’ve been confirmed to be found from Sweden, I wouldn’t be surprised if they grew in Finland aswell. Very strong odor as with my other blueing Pholiotina finds since 2014.

results.notes:
Photographed at the town farmers’ market. Only one person was selling edulis, while everybody else had only chanterelles.
Lithuania had another tough summer for fungi, even though it wasn’t s nearly as bad as last year, with all the heat and drought. Still, precipitation was spotty and not plentiful enough in the first two months of the season. Druskininkai received just 1.3" of rain in the first two week of August. However, I was finding only saprobes and a few russulas in the aftermath of this precipitation (14th—>19th), and the first substantial mycorrhizals didn’t start showing up till the 20th. Then the area got another 1"+ of rain early on the 21st (just two days prior to my departure!), and I finally started finding “real mushrooms” the following day. Yet, no edulis or chanterelles for me, and I looked hard.
results.location_name: Druskininkai, Lithuania

results.notes:
The first bolete on the scene following the 1.3" of rain in the first two weeks of August. Growing in an open area (a small meadow) in Scots pine woods. It rained an additional 1.4" the following day, and in a few hours these critters were growing gregariously everywhere. In one location (3 pines in a birch grove) I counted at least three dozen! Local mushroom pickers were plucking them out eagerly. Slimy as they come, they are actually good pickled. The marinade has the same slimy consistency… if you are into that kind of stuff. :-)
A sample was preserved in CTAB buffer, to be submitted for sequencing soon.

results.notes:
Collected on the Ohio Mushroom Society’s 2019 summer foray. Growing scattered in moss in swampy soil in a hardwood forest. Acer spp., Quercus spp., Ulmus spp., Carya spp., Fagus grandifolia, Ostrya virginiana and other hardwoods present in the area. Caps and stems slimy. Gills short-decurrent and turn greenish in drying. Clamps present. Pileipellis an ixocutis. Gill edges gelatinized with filamentous cheilocystidia. Pleurocystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate with medallion clamps at the bases. Spores smooth, hyaline and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (4.6) 4.8 – 6.5 (6.7) × (3.3) 3.7 – 4.6 (5) µm, Q = (1.1) 1.3 – 1.5 (1.7); N = 30, Me = 5.8 × 4.1 µm; Qe = 1.4

Mirrored on iNaturalist at https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/32147919

results.notes:
Growing from the base of Populus x canescens.
A sample was preserved in CTAB buffer and will be submitted for sequencing.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted on 28-Jun-20):
> A clean and contiguous full-length nrITS (ITS1-5.8S-ITS2) sequence of 621 bps was obtained from this organism by Dr. Kudzma. The three subloci are 246, 160 and 215 bps long in this species. There are two ambiguous characters, “R” (A/G) and “Y” (C/T); both appear at the start of ITS1.
> BLASTn-250 results are summarized in the appended unrooted tree. The following criteria were applied for the tree building:
1) Selected all accessions labeled ‘C. atramentaria’ (highlighted in terracotta)
2) Selected a large sampling of accessions with at least 90% similarity to the query, the vast majority of which were identified to species
3) Selected all accessions originating from TYPE collections (highlighted in green)
> In the phylogram, MO379875 shows up next to a cluster of four accessions. Of these, the only realistic match are two records – DQ486694 and FJ168569 – corresponding to the same voucher: ‘Coprinopsis atramentaria PMB922’ from Washington, USA (100% cover, 617/621= 99.4% similar; 3 shared ambiguities and a G/T mismatch in a mixed homopolymeric stretch). None of these mismatches happen to be significant, and it appears that MO379875 is conspecific with the WA voucher. While accession ‘Coprinopsis atramentaria BP-12’ from India (MK386821) is 99.5% similar, the query cover is only 64%, as most of its ITS2 and the first 47 bps of ITS1 are missing. The 4th accession, KT833863, is only 95.8% similar, so it clearly another species.
As to the other 10 accessions in the phylogram labeled ‘C. atramentaria’, they may represent as many as 8 taxa. It’s not clear which of them represent the true C. atramentaria.
> Frustrated with the lack of closure to the identity of MO379875 due to the mess with accession labeling/voucher ID in GenBank, I did some online digging and found this 2015 paper titled “Type studies on Coprinus dunarum Stoll” (https://www.researchgate.net/...). The paper features many sequences of reliably identified Coprinopsis vouchers deposited in both GenBank and UNITE databases. Satisfyingly, among several ITS sequence codes logged under Coprinopsis romagnesiana I found the aforementioned GB accession FJ168569 from Washington, USA, closely matching the ITS of MO379875. Additional sequences of the European C. romagnesiana can be found in UNITE.

results.notes:
> Growing on an isolated mossy lawn/yard of an uninhabited house near a large red oak, with a “doublet” of Populus x canescens just 10 yards away. The poplars can be seen in the photos, and these are associated with obs 379875 (Coprinopsis romagnesiana). The other trees nearby, closer to the road, are young oaks and maples. There is no birch, but a 25-30 foot fir or spruce is found next to the oak. The habitat of this location can be viewed in street view of Google maps. Interestingly, this location gave rise to totally different mushrooms during my previous visit in August 2018 (A. pantherina & Russula spp.).
I left this cluster to mature and instead collected and sampled for DNA a single and comparably aged specimen from about a yard away. However, the cluster was discovered by local or visiting mushroom pickers the next day. The mycelium produced 3 more fruitbodies by next morning (22nd), but they also disappeared before the day was over.
> The big 2005 Persoonia paper by den Bakker and Noordeloos, the third of a series of 4 manuscripts published in 2004-2007, thoroughly describes all the species of the genus Leccinum found in Europe and elucidates their taxonomic status.1 There are only 4 orange/red-capped taxa with marginal flaps (sect./subsect. Leccinum) reported therein: L. aurantiacum, L. albostipitatum, L. versipelle, and L. vulpinum.1 The first species (=quercinum =populinum =salicola) is characterized by reddish-brown caps, reddish to dark reddish-brown scabers in young and mature fruitbodies, respectively, and its mycorrhizal association with several deciduous hosts, notably poplar (aspen), oak and birch (i.e., no host specificity). L. albostipitatum, described as a new taxon by the authors in the same paper (=aurantiacum sensu Korhonen 1995 =leucopodium Pers. sensu Den Bakker), is partial to poplars, and has light orange caps and whitish to light brown scabers in young and mature fruitbodies, respectively. Next, L. versipelle (=callitrichum =cerenum =percandium =roseotinctum) is a strict birch associate with a light brownish to orange cap and grayish to blackish scabers even in young fruitbodies. Lastly, L. vulpinum (=piceinum ?), mycorrhizal only with conifers, has reddish-brown caps and grayish to blackish scabers in young fruitbodies.
With the above information applied to MO379895, versipelle and vulpinum can be eliminated based on the basic morphology and habitat/ecology (notwithstanding the small conifer). This leaves aurantiacum and albostipitatum, both of which are hosted by poplars. While the recorded cap colors are not exactly consistent with the description of aurantiacum, the presence of reddish-brown scabers on the outward-facing stipital surface at this tender age appears to be a strike against albostipitatum. On the other hand, note that the scabers are white on the inner surface, facing the adjacent sporocarps. However, this is consistent with the aforementioned authors’ observation that aurantiacum growing in grass (i.e., in relative shade/away from light) can also have white or pallid stipital ornamentation.1 Based on this preliminary analysis, L. aurantiacum emerges as the choice candidate. Will DNA support this identification?
> DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted on 1-Apr-21):
- A contiguous nrDNA sequence of 1494 characters was obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma and posted to this observation. It consists of the last 19 bases of nrSSU, followed by a full-length ITS sequence of 1411 bps (!) and then by the first 64 bps of nrLSU. The ITS1 sublocus is 934 nucleotides long (!), undoubtedly due to the presence of numerous mini-satellite tandem repeats (a feature not seen elsewhere in Boletaceae), while the ITS2 region is 316 characters long. It took 4 separate reads originating from the equal number of primers to put this sequence together on account of its remarkable length, as well as a single point of heterogeneity located toward the end of the ITS2 region.
- The below analysis and interpretation of BLASTn results was made possible by the pioneering molecular studies of the genus Leccinum in Europe by den Bakker, Noordeloos et al. in 2004-2007.1,2,3 Although these publications are >15 y.o., their relevance is unchallenged in the absence of more recent publications on the subject of European scaber stalks. Due to the sheer length of ITS locus in Leccinum and in view of the fact that using long sequence to mine GenBank has lead to “biased” hit lists for the default BLASTn-100, separate BLAST searches for ITS1 and ITS2 became necessary.
- As it turns out, there are no full-length ITS sequences of the true Leccinum aurantiacum in GenBank (as of early April 2021), and whatever partial ITS sequences present there under that name likely represent more than one species (I didn’t attempt to verify their identities). The early accession AF454569 ‘Leccinum aurantiacum from Belgium’ by den Bakker & Noordeloos is a full-length ITS sequence, but the voucher was misidentified and the accession title has not been corrected. In Ref. 2 (2004a), for which AF454569 was procured, the corresponding collection is recorded as ‘Leccinum aurantiacum voucher rw1656 from Ardennes, France’. However, in Ref. 3 (2004b), this voucher is identified as ‘Leccium leucopodium’. Finally, in Ref. 1 (2005), the authors publish the corresponding taxon represented by AF454569 under a new name, Leccinum albostipitatum den Bakker & Noordel.1,4
- Regrettably, den Bakker & Noordeloos’ sampling of sect. Leccinum in their first paper (Ref. 2) is limited to only four vouchers/species; the other three full-length ITS sequence are AF454574 (L. versipelle), AF454578/AF454579 (L. piceinum), and AF454580 (L. vulpinum). Since the ITS1 sublocus in Leccinum was found to be phylogenetically uninformative (Ref. 2), no additional ITS1 or full-length ITS sequences of reliably identified European scaber stalks have been generated henceforth by the authors. At the same time, the usefulness of the ITS1 spacer for barcoding purposes is also limited by its intraspecific variability stemming from complex patterns of mini-satellites/tandem repeats. In their next publication, Ref. 3 (2004b), the authors focus their phylogenetic efforts on the ITS2 spacer and single-copy protein coding gene Gapdh. Therein, the conserved nature of the ITS2 sublocus in Leccinum responsible for the inferior phylogenetic signal and barcoding capacity (species resolution), particularly in sect. Leccinum, vis-a-vis those of Gapdh is established and discussed.3
- Alignments of the full-length ITS1 sequences of MO379895 with AF454569 (L. albostipitatum ) and AF454574 (L. versipelle ) are shown in Figs. 1 & 2, respectively. The first alignment shows that while albostipitatum has a contiguous 396 bps (!) indel in the middle, the spacers to the left and right of it are 100% identical. The second alignment shows that the ITS1 regions in MO379895 and L. versipelle are of more comparable length (934 vs 896 bps). The 2 indels in AF454574 are only 19-20 bps long and are structurally related to each other; in addition, there are other very short (1-3 bps) indels in either sequence due to variable-length homopolymers. The remaining 12 unique mismatching positions represent single nucleotide polymorphism events (SNPs). I think the ITS1 sequences of MO379895 and L. versipelle are sufficiently different to conclude that the two collections are not conspecific.
- As far as the ITS2 spacer is concerned, that of MO379895 is identical (sans the sole ambiguity) to that of AF454569 (L. albostipitatum). This is the top hit in GenBank at 99.7% similarity and there are no other matches or close hits associated with Ref. 3 that sampled numerous vouchers of Leccinum aurantiacum (listed as “L. populinum” and “L. quercinum” in GenBank) and L. versipelle.3 As a matter of fact, those ITS2 sequences of aurantiacum are only 94% similar to that of MO379895 — see sequence alignment in Fig. 3.
Conclusions: Based on the above assessment from gross morphology, habitat, as well as inferences from ITS1 & ITS2 sequences from the published literature, the present collection is best identified as Leccinum albostipitatum. The overall utility of the Internal Transcribe Spacer (nrITS) for reliable species identification in sect. Leccinum is undermined – on one hand – by the complex structure of ITS1, leading to intraspecific variability, and – on the other – by the conserved nature of ITS2 in most taxa from either side of the Atlantic.2, 3. Any inferences derived from ITS sequence analyses within Leccinum should probably be verified by alternative loci possessing superior phylogenetic resolution; however, this practice would then question the continued use of ITS to study Leccinum in North America.
References:
1 den Bakker & Noordeloos, “A revision of European species of Leccinum Gray and notes on extralimital species”; Persoonia 18(4): 511-587 (2005)
2 den Bakker et al., “An ITS phylogeny of Leccinum and an analysis of the evolution of minisatellite-like sequences within ITS1”; Mycologia 96: 102-118 (2004a)
3 den Bakker et al., “Evolution and host specificity in the ectomycorrhizal genus Leccinum”; New Phytologist 163: 201-215 (2004b)
4 http://www.speciesfungorum.org/...

results.notes:
A single fruitbody growing in grass in a birch grove, with a few Scots pines nearby. It must have sprouted the day before I found it. It rained heavily in the morning/early afternoon of the 21st, so it must have grown some more thanks to this moisture. It was found just 2 yards to the east from C. prunulus of obs 379939.
The cap is medium-dark caramel brown mottled with lighter areas of beige. The stipe is dingy white. The scabers are dark brown to blackish-brown. The pore surface is white with some brown staining likely due to the environmental factors; the pore mouths are closed off/compressed (immature). The somewhat waterlogged flesh is whitish to grayish-cream, with some darker brownish streaky areas in the cortex of the lower stipe and base, fibrous/pithy in the lower half of stipe, slowly staining brownish mostly in the cap, but not bluing at all anywhere.
A tissue sample was preserved in CTAB buffer and will be submitted for sequencing (ITS) soon.

results.notes:
Over a dozen specimens at different stages of development growing gregariously in grass under mature linden (basswood) and maple on the grounds of the Hotel Violeta by the Neman River. Judging by the size of the immature fruitbodies, it was a robust species. A slight neutral odor, cannot say it smelled like phenol. Cap margin and stipe base stained yellow when flesh was pressed on with fingers. The exposed context didn’t really change color.
A tissue sample was preserved in CTAB buffer and will be submitted for sequencing soon.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion:
> A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence of 875 bps supported by forward and reverse reads was obtained by Dr. Kudzma from this collection and uploaded to this post. It consists of a full-length ITS sequence of 653 bps bookended by SSU and LSU fragments of 46 and 176 bps, respectively. ITS1 is 290 bps long, 5.8S is 160 bps long, and ITS2 is 203 bps long. There are no ambiguous characters, it’s a single haplotype.
> BLASTn-100 of this ITS sequence returned a hit list containing 14 accessions of Agaricus xanthodermus with 99.7-100% similarity as top hits; one of these, KJ609510, was derived from R.W. Kerrigan’s collection (100% similar). There are also 2 matching accessions labeled as ‘abruptibulbus’ and ‘pseudopratensis’, which are likely misidentifications. There were 4 other accessions in the hit list labeled as ‘xanthodermus’ (only 98.5-98.8% similar) that are also presumed to have been misidentified.
> Based on the above result, as well as a pre-DNA identification from the photos as A. xanthodermus by Dr. Kerrigan (15-Jan-2020 personal communication), the identity of this voucher is now well established.

results.notes:
The most exciting fungal find of my trip that came not a moment too soon – “boil first then okay”. :-) I’ve never seen luridus in the flesh before, and will probably never see it again.
Two young, yet robust, fruiting bodies growing side by side in short grass under a mature maple, but with a single mature red oak and two hybrid poplars/aspens in the immediate vicinity. These latter trees are associated with my two earlier posts, obs 379875 and obs 379895. My guess that the oak is the host.
One of the fruitbodies was picked and photographed extensively. The other one was left untouched and was photographed in situ (thumbnail photo) the next morning, shortly before my departure from the hotel.
The overall morphology is visible from the images. These were very hefty and hard-fleshed mushrooms.
A tissue sample was preserved in CTAB buffer and will soon be submitted for sequencing.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 13-Jun-20):
> A clean and contiguous full-length nrITS (ITS1-5.8S-ITS2) sequence of 635 bps fully supported by forward and reverse reads was obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma. The ITS1 and ITS2 loci are 248 bps and 226 bps long, respectively, while the 5.8S region is of the standard length of 161 bps for Boletaceae. There is a single ambiguity, “S” (C/G)” in the ITS1 region.
> A BLASTn-250 search gave multiple close matches (99.1-99.8% similarity) to accessions of the European Suillellus luridus as top hits. Thus, the identity of this collection has been ascertained.
> An unrooted phylogram consisting of 50+ Suillellus accessions from the BLASTn hit list was uploaded to this post (Fig. 1). Note that North American collections frequently identified in the field as S. luridus are only 95-96% similar and constitute a distinct, undescribed sister taxon. In the phylogram I aptly refer to it as Suillellus ‘ameriluridus’. For examples of this species on MO confirmed by DNA (discussions to be posted soon), see obs 327823, obs 334282 and obs 383792.

results.notes:
Collected by Ash Molnar on the Ohio Mushroom Society’s 2019 summer foray. Growing singly on a chunk of well-rotted Quercus wood in a forest containing Tsuga canadensis, Fagus canadensis, Sassafras albidum, Quercus spp., Acer spp., Carya spp. and some other hardwoods. Fairly dried-out when collected. Cap and stem dry. Basal mycelium white. All structures inamyloid. Pileipellis a cutis, lacking inflated elements and encrusting pigment. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia absent. Spores hyaline, thin-walled and smooth. Spore measurements: (4.5) 4.6 – 5.8 (5.9) × (2.4) 2.6 – 3.8 (3.9) µm, Q = (1.4) 1.5 – 2 (2.2); N = 30, Me = 5.2 × 3.1 µm; Qe = 1.7

results.notes: About 15-20 mushrooms collected, fruiting on pine needle litter (about 1 to 2 per pine needle), during a dry spell around mid-afternoon, thus they were rather dry when collected; Macro: Pileus approximately 8 to 10 mm broad, essentially broadly convex to plane, with a small depressed center, whitish to a very pale greyish-buff, pruinose or ‘suede’-like, margin incurved, though expanding when revived in water; Lamellae creamy white, more or less concolorous with pileus, broadly annexed to adnate with stipe, slightly intervenose, occasionally forked, lamellulae infrequent and irregular; Stipe about 2 mm thick and around 15 – 20 mm long, subequal with base slightly attenuated and a compressed mid area, becoming twisted/contorted when dry, light greyish-brown at apex and slightly darker below, prominently pruinose throughout length; Odor/Taste nondistinctive, did not taste; Micro: Basidiospores ellipsoid to pip/tear-shaped, hyaline and smooth, inamyloid, (5.5) 6.0 – 7.1 (7.3 – 7.5) x (2.6 – 2.8) 2.9 – 3.1 (3.3 – 3.5) μm, Q = 1.8 – 2.7; N=34, (95% Conf: L x W = 6.4 – 6.7 × 2.9 – 3.1 μm, Q = 2.1 – 2.3); Basidia clavate to inflated-cylindrical, (20) 21 – 31 (40) x 5 – 6, (95% Conf: L x W = 23.6 – 28.6 × 5.3 – 5.7 μm); Pleurocystidia absent or undifferentiated from fusioid-shaped basidiole elements; Cheilocystidia abundant at lamellar edge, fusoid to ventricose, consistently irregular in shape, with/without numerous protrusions/knobs, (14 – 17) 20 – 34 (65) x (4) 5 – 7 (8 – 10) μm, N = 24, (95% Conf: L x W: 23.2 – 30.6 × 5.5 – 6.7 μm); Pileipellis a cutis consisting of interwoven variable hyphae, branched, tuberculate, septate, hyaline and thin-walled, termini various, consisting of clavate to coralloid-type elements and also some poorly-formed ‘Rameales’-like elements; Stipitipellis a cutis, hyaline to very pale brownish; Caulocystidia/Stipe Vesture consisting of clavate to cylindro-clavate cystidial elements, septate, somewhat thick-walled with faint incrustations, also consisting of hairs (caulosetae?) of which were fusiform-lanceolate in shape, abundant, thin to slightly thick-walled; Clamp Connections present and abundant at bases of cystidial elements and terminal hyphae, also present at septums of hyphae, though not at every septum.
results.location_name: Panola Mountain State Park, Rockdale Co., Georgia, USA

results.notes: Collected around 11:00 am, following a day or two of intermittent rain, during a very dry period. Tiny basidiomes scattered amongst forest litter, fruiting on pine needles and oak leaves; Macro: Pileus ranging from ~ 3 to 6 (7) mm broad, plane to plano-convex to somewhat depressed, pale buff to creamy-whitish, disc pale greyish-brown, lightly pruinose, margin even to rugose-striate, sometimes incurved; Lamellae adnate to barely annexed, distant, whitish, slightly lighter in color than the pileus, somewhat intervenose towards pileus margin, infrequently forked, lamellulae present and irregular, edges even to somewhat fringed (not serrated); Stipe about 25 to 35 mm in height and approximately 1 mm thick, even, pale brown, pruinose to pubescent throughout, insititious, dainty; Odor/Taste odor nondistinctive, possibly due to lack of moisture/age etc, did not taste; Rhizomorphs present, abundant, pale to whitish, some up to about 40 mm in length, branched; Micro: Basidiospores ellipsoid to subamygdaliform, smooth, hyaline, ~ (6.0 – 6.5) 6.8 – 8.2 (8.4 – 9.1) x (3.0 – 3.2) 3.3 – 4.0 (4.1 – 4.8) μm; Q = 1.6 – 2.6; N = 46; (95% Conf: L x W = 7.2 – 7.7 × 3.5 – 3.8 μm; Q = 2.0 – 2.14); Basidia clavate, 4-spored, hyaline, ~ 18 – 25 × 6 – 8 μm; Basidioles clavate to subfusioid or ampulliform, similar dimensions as basidia; Pleurocystidia consisting of either cystioid-like elements similar to basidioles though with more of a fusoid/fusiform/mamillate shape or representing actual pleurocystidia, dimensions similar to basidioles/basidia though slightly slimmer on average; Cheilocystidia inconsistent amongst each basidioma, some with decent amounts and others with scare amounts, also extremely variable in shape, clavate to fusoid to infated-cylindrical, sometimes without any diverticula or broad appendage-like protrusions, more frequently with knobs and short diverticula, ~ 15 – 28 × 6 – 9 μm; (95% Conf: L x W = 18.8 – 22.5 × 6.5 – 7.4 μm; Q = 2.7 – 3.3); Pileipellis also very variable, elements towards margin consisting of diverticulate and branched hyphae with Rameale-like terminal elements, frequently inflated, the elements closer to the disc consisting of more of a hymeniderm with clavate to obpyriform terminal elements with and without knobby diverticula, the disc also with some poorly formed Rameale-like structures, appearing similar to the cheilocystidia, though generally more thick-walled and with more broadened/obtuse diverticula, septate and hyaline to pale yellowish/brownish/golden; Pileal trama consisting of interwoven hyphae, mostly smooth, thin-walled; Stipitipellis a cutis, generally thin-walled hyphae, hyaline to pale brown, smooth; Caulocystidia consistent/frequent throughout length of stipe, generally smooth, infrequently branched, thin-walled though some termini with thick walls (~ 2 μm wide), termainal elements varying from inflated clavate to obclavate, some with knobs/diverticula to poorly formed Rameale-type cells, very similar to elements of pileipellis over disc of pileus; Clamp Connections present and frequent, sometimes appearing inconspicuous in pileipellis.

results.notes: Very tiny, entire sporocarp ~ 1 cm broad, very fragile, fruiting from a well-decayed, barkless pine log. Macro: Pileus about 7 or 8 mm broad, convex, broadly umbonate, whitish with slightly darker disc, disc off-white to light gray with granule-like fibrils (or at least appearing superficially granulose), tiny appressed fibrils towards margin, of which is slightly appendiculate; Lamellae white, yellowing in age, crowded, essentially free from stipe; Stipe ~ 1mm thick and about 10 mm long, tapered towards apex, white, finely fibrillose above annulus, fibrillose to pruinose below annulus, no discoloration noticed in age/handling; Odor/Taste Odor non-distinctive, did not taste; Micro: Basidiospores generally elliptical to infrequently broadly cylindric, thick-walled, hyaline, dextrinoid, without conspicuous germ pore, ~ (4.8 – 5.1) 5.3 – 7.5 (8.0 – 9.5) x (3.0 – 3.15) 3.3 – 4.1 (4.5 – 4.9) μm; Q = 1.6 – 2.3; N = 44; (95% Conf: L x W = 6.1 – 6.7 × 3.5 – 3.7 μm; Q = 1.7 – 1.8); Basidia clavate, sometimes inflated towards apex, generally 2 to 3 sterigmata present, ~ (14) 17 – 21 × 6 – 7 μm; Pleurocystidia not found; Cheilocystidia generally cylindrical or clavate with rounded apex or also with both a short apical ‘knob-like’ protrusion or a long flexuous rostrum upwards of 35 – 40 μm and about 5 μm wide, actual cystidia up to 40 – 80 μm long on average (including rostrum/protrusion); Pileus covering consisting of variable hyphae, cylindrical to fusiform, mostly versiform, septate, inflated termini, and also scattered areas of globose to ovoid to broadly fusiform elements, sometimes in chains, generally these are terminal elements; Clamp Connections not observed.

results.notes: Found on lawn of an a apartment buildings, looks like a possible blue ringer ( Ps. Stuntzii ). Has hygrophanous cap, membranous annulus with purple spores and stained blue on ring. Beat up the stem and did’nt notice any bluing as the stem was pinched but more brown when squished, noticed very slight greenish bruish on cap in some areas. But without the stem turning blue, I have doubts and would appreciate an Id. ( Update: used references from Paul Kroeger’s “Magic Mushrooms” History and Modern Use: from Central America to British Columbia as reference for Psilocybe Fimetaria. Psilocybe Stuntzii photos for reference from Caleb Brown, the photo with the hygrophanous fading on the caps in reference 3 on right side are pretty much identical to the one I found. photos at bottom are from the lecture and Caleb as reference. )

Open mossy area with hickory, other hardwoods including one small oak. No conifers.

Last photo shows broadly ellipsoid to subglobose objects of undetermined identity…? Also, seen is an intact sub-chain of Tolypocladium spores.

results.notes:
a group of 15-20 fruits found growing under conifer trees. About 200 meters from the Blanchard river. Lots of rain and sunshine for the past week. Very wet, been raining all day today. Most were hiding under the fallen tree needles. Slimy, slightly sticky cap surface. Smells almost nutty, very light but pleasant mushroom smell. Maybe yellow staining when dissected. Left residual yellowing on fingertips when the stipe was handled.

Update on associated conifer trees:
Decidedly Eastern white pine (Pinus strobus): needles are soft and flexible, greenish blue, bundles of 5
